data.title: Nothing But the Truth (2008)
data.meta_description: When reporter Rachel Armstrong writes a story that reveals the identity of a covert CIA operative, the government demands that Rachel reveal her source. She defies the special prosecutor and is thrown in jail. Meanwhile, her attorney, Albert Burnside argues her case all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court.
data.text:
Nothing But The Truth is one of those rare films that manages to walk a straight line and still be groundbreaking. Rod Lurie's masterful script combined with the commanding performances from the entire ensemble create a piece where each piece of dialogue is razor sharp and rips off of the screen. It's impossible to keep your eyes off of these characters as they work their way through a legal labyrinth where the question of loyalty versus personal sacrifice is raised to it's ultimate stakes. In the same vein as David Mamet's Redbelt, it takes it's main character and tests their honor over and over again, forcing them to prove how much their principles mean to them. On the surface it…

Wait! You've never heard of this movie but you should check it out! Less a whodunit than a “wouldyoudoit”—it's an effective little civics thought-experiment: What would *you* do in these circumstances? Protect your source? Not write the article? Is the 1st amendment applicable? The 5th? What are all the competing ethical claims? Do you have the courage of your convictions? Would you prefer to be zealously defended by Matt Dillon or Alan Alda?!?

Pairs well with The Contender (another ethical quandary directed by Rod Lurie). But also, going a little prison-pairing-stir-crazy, try: The Mauritanian (Jodie Foster and Gitmo prisoner), Camp X-Ray (Kristen Stewart and Gitmo prisoner), Breaker Morant (British government and Australia soldier-prisoners), The Mustang (Unsentimental prison equine therapy for hardened…
